thread.section_title: World Travel | Overseas and International World Travel | The Advertiser
thread.title: Jetstar and Virgin Australia begin flights from Bali after ash cloud fear | The
thread.title_full: Jetstar and Virgin Australia begin flights from Bali after ash cloud fear | The Advertiser

author: By Komang Erviani, Cindy Wockner, Robyn Ironside and wires
title: Jetstar and Virgin Australia begin flights from Bali after ash cloud fear | The
text:
VIRGIN Australia has joined Jetstar in resuming flights to and from Bali to pick up thousands of passengers stranded for days when a volcanic ash cloud forced the closure of the island’s main airport.
Ngurah Rai International Airport in Denpasar opened at midday on Saturday but Virgin Australia and Jetstar checked to ensure the conditions were safe.
Virgin Australia sent an observation flight to Denpasar so pilots could have visual confirmation of the conditions before recommencing operations.
With the safety thumbs-up given, Virgin Australia scheduled flights out of Denpasar to Adelaide, Brisbane, Melbourne and Perth on Saturday evening. Flights to Sydney and a second flight to Brisbane would depart early Sunday morning.
Virgin Australia flights from Denpasar to Australia will be operating this evening. More info here: http://t.co/DM7gOEbx0V
— Virgin Australia (@VirginAustralia) July 11, 2015 Earlier on Saturday, a Jetstar spokesman said the airline had determined it was safe to fly all scheduled services to Bali that evening after careful assessment of the latest Volcanic Ash Advisory Centre (VAAC) information.
“We’re pleased that flying conditions allow us to start bringing people back to Australia on return services from tomorrow morning,” the spokesman said.
Denpasar Airport on #Bali has reopened after closure due to #MtRaung ash cloud. http://t.co/IFbPbA83On pic.twitter.com/1Kwyytrpa0
— Flightradar24 (@flightradar24) July 11, 2015 Long lines quickly formed at Denpasar airport on Saturday afternoon as passengers queued in the hope of their flights being rescheduled quickly, with dozens of planes listed for departure in the evening.
Flights to Singapore, Kuala Lumpur and Jakarta were among the first to depart, according to air traffic website flightradar24.com .
Trikora Harjo, the airport’s general manager, said things were slowly returning to normal at the terminal, with passengers queuing up to check in and crews preparing planes for departures.
“It’s a bit crowded, because of the cancellations,” he told AFP. “I think maybe after one day, or two days, things will become normal again.”
Both Jetstar and Virgin Australia said additional services from Bali to Australia were being organised for Sunday.
However Virgin cautioned travellers against thinking the volcanic ash cloud disruptions were completely over.
“Please note that Mt Raung continues to erupt at this time and it is likely that operations could be disrupted again over the next few days if there are changes to wind conditions,” they said in a statement, adding conditions would be monitored closely.
Mt Raung erupted on July 2, emitting plumes of ash which can choke jet engines. The volcano is about 150 kilometres west of Denpasar airport, the main airport for those heading to Bali. Denpasar airport was closed on Thursday because of the ash, along with nearby regional terminals including Lombok.
The ash grounded planes from Virgin Australia, Jetstar, Garuda and AirAsia.
Ngurah Rai airport authority chief, Yusfandri Gona, said that many airlines were proposing changes to use bigger aircraft when they resume flying.
“Virgin has proposed to use an Airbus 330, changing from Boeing 737 800, that they normally use. Some airlines have also proposed extra flights,” Mr Gona said.
“We expect that the airport operation will be back to normal within three days.” he said.
Thousands of Australians are believed to be stranded in Bali as a result of disruption by the ash plume from the erupting Mount Raung.
Chaos ... passengers queue up at the international terminal at Bali's Ngurah Rai airport in Denpasar. Picture: AFP Source: AFP
Townsville lawyer, Anderson Telford, was due to fly home on Thursday evening and is now hopeful of being on a Sunday afternoon flight.
Mr Telford was in Bali where an Australian client is facing court on drugs charges. That case too was postponed unexpectedly.
He said whilst the situation was frustrating and unfortunate, it was based on safety considerations.
“It is unfortunate, nothing much can be done about it. I think generally everyone accepts you can’t control the weather,” Mr Telford said at the airport.
“I think everyone accepts when a decision is made about safety that safety must always come first, everyone understands that,” he said.
Lawyer Anderson Telford, who was due to fly Bali on Thursday night, complained about information flow. Picture: Salman Al-Farizi Source: News Corp Australia
Mr Telford said however that the information flow about what was happening could have been a little clearer for stranded traveller.
“It could be clearer. I suppose it is regular but it is repetitive.”
Gold Coast woman Monique Williams and her sister Renee Le Clerc were due to fly home on Jetstar on Wednesday evening after an eight day holiday. They have now rebooked on Air Asia through Kuala Lumpur and hope to be home on Sunday.
Ms Williams said she was initially upset at missing her daughter’s birthday on Saturday but said it is nobody’s fault and one can only laugh about the situation now.
“It is one of those things that happens, Everyone is pretty angry at Jetstar from what we can gather but if the planes are small and it is not safe to fly then I don’t want to be in a plane that is not safe to fly in,” Ms Williams said.
She said gaining information on the situation had been frustrating. She spent 90 minute on the phone at one stage and on another occasion was cut off.
Monique Williams (left) and her sister Rene Le Clerc wait at Ngurah International Rai Airport in Dempasar, Bali. Picture: Salman Al-Farizi Source: News Corp Australia
A Jetstar spokesman said extra services would be used on Sunday to help clear the backlog of stranded passengers.
The ash plume from Mount Raung has played havoc with flight schedules since mid week and led to the closure of Ngurah Rai International Airport. Volcanic ash is known to cause serious damage to aircraft and can lead to engine “flame outs”.
Thousands of Australians are believed to be stranded in Bali as a result of flight cancellations.
Thousands more have been unable to travel to the Indonesian holiday Island from Australia.
July is typically one of the biggest months for Aussie tourists visiting Bali, with about 99,000 departures last year.
The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has over 4000 Australians currently registered in Bali, but a spokeswoman said the real number was thought to be significantly higher.
Senior meteorologist at the Volcanic Ash Advisory Centre in Darwin, Stephanie Bond, said the plume had moved to the south of the volcano which meant Denpasar had been cleared of ash.
“Most of Bali is clear, there’s just a little bit in the far western parts,” said Ms Bond.
“We’re expecting conditions to remain the same for the next three days with winds coming from the north.
“Beyond that, it’s difficult to say, as volcanoes are unpredictable and Mount Raung is continuing to erupt.”
Long wait ... passengers line up after their flights were cancelled at Bali's international airport. Picture: AP Source: AP
Jetstar Australia and New Zealand CEO David Hall said the situation which has left thousands of Australians stranded was “extremely regrettable”.
“We share our customers’ frustrations with the situation to Bali,” said Mr Hall.
“It’s extremely regrettable that our customers’ holidays have been spoiled by these disruptions and that we can’t provide the certainty we would like to due to the unpredictability of the volcanic ash cloud surrounding this airport.”
He indicated Qantas may join Jetstar in providing additional services to clear the backlog of passengers once the ash cloud cleared.
“We have teams working around the clock, monitoring conditions in Bali and assisting customers as best we can in these trying circumstances,” Mr Hall said.
Causing trouble ... Mount Raung in Banyuwangi, East Java, Indonesia, spews ash. Picture: AP Source: AP
Authorities raised the alert status of Mount Raung, a 3300-metre volcano, late last month to the second highest level after it began to spew lava and ash high into the air forcing the planes to stop flying.
Passengers impacted by the flight cancellations have been left to fend for themselves in Bali, with many sleeping on the airport floor.
Airlines don’t provide accommodation or meal vouchers during such events because they are deemed beyond their control.
Fees for rebootings, cancellations and flight changes are being waived for limited periods by Jetstar, Virgin Australia, AirAsia and Garuda.
The smoke and ash from Indonesian volcano Mount Raung ... It began erupting last week causing chaos and cancellation of flights to and from Bali. Picture: Instagram photo by @tanandsmiley (Tanya Sandow) Source: Instagram
Senior meteorologist at the Volcanic Ash Advisory Centre, Stephanie Bond, said the last time Mount Raung erupted, it continued to erupt for many weeks.
“The volcano is continually emitting ash and the winds are staying in the same direction,” said Ms Bond.
“For the foreseeable future there won’t be any reprieve. Winds generally move due to weather systems, and there’s no strong driver of winds in the area.”
Bali is a favourite holiday destination for Australians. Crowds of foreign tourists were stranded at Bali’s Ngurah Rai airport, waiting for further information about their flights.
Air New Zealand said a flight due to depart from Bali on Saturday afternoon had been rescheduled to leave early on Sunday, conditions permitting.
Grounded ... The departure screens at Sydney International airport as flights to Bali have been cancelled. Picture: Supplied. Source: News Corp Australia
The Insurance Council of Australia has advised travellers to confirm the compensation or alternative arrangement details of their travel insurance policies.
Virgin customers can change their booking to another flight within 14 days at no extra charge or receive a full travel credit. Virgin is advising customers to call 13 67 89 to rearrange their bookings.
Melbourne resident Brendan McCarthy was told his flight home from Bali on Friday had been cancelled until at least Monday.
Other travellers were being told their flights could be delayed until July 23, he said.
“We’ve been here for two weeks, have changed accommodation three times now,” Mr McCarthy told AAP.
As well as missing work, medical appointments and sporting commitments, he and his girlfriend are also facing additional unplanned travel costs that they hope to recoup through travel insurance.
“A fantastic holiday is now having a really bad ending,” Mr McCarthy said.
A Perth couple said they had been left without cash after their flight home was grounded.
Ross and Leigh-Ann McNulty said they spent $3000 to fly their family of four home with AirAsia on Friday after their Jetstar flights were cancelled. But they faced at least another day in Bali after Denpasar airport was closed.
Delayed ... passengers rest in the international terminal at Bali's Ngurah Rai airport in Denpasar waiting for information of flight delays due to volcanic ash near Indonesia's resort island. Picture: AFP Source: AFP
They told AAP that they were desperate to get home as Mrs McNulty has run out of medication and Mr McNulty needs to work. They weren’t able to claim the costs under their travel insurance and were borrowing money from friends.
“My husband’s self-employed, we might have to end up declaring bankruptcy now because things have got that bad,” Mrs McNulty said.
“This has just financially ruined us really.”
Mr McNulty said they pleaded with Jetstar to prioritise them for medical reasons, but nothing worked.
“It’s turning out to be the Bali holiday from hell basically,” he said.
“We love the Balinese people, but we’ll probably never come back as a result of the debacle of the airlines.
“I realise they’ve got to put the safety of passengers first, but the actual way they’ve been so quiet and not let us know is just devastating.
“It’s not good enough, we paid good money to board these flights and the least they could do is look after us when they make so much money.”
Originally published as Jetstar and Virgin start Bali flights
